question: Which of the following conditions is characterized by a spike and dome appearance of the glomerular basement membrane on electron microscopy?

A 70-year-old female came to the emergency for dysuria and hematuria. Urine D/R showed numerous pus cells and proteinuria. X-ray showed an asymmetrical contracted kidney with blunting of the calyceal system. She was diagnosed with reflux nephropathy. Which one of the following complications is associated with reflux nephropathy?
According to Pakistani law, abortion is justified only in which condition?

answers.option: To save the life of the mother
In a woman with large family
If it is performed by a trained doctor
In a case of unmarried women

question: A dead body of a girl was brought for autopsy. On examination, she was pregnant, and severe injuries were observed in her pelvic area. On inquiry, her mother told that she tried to criminally induce abortion during which she died within minutes. What is the most probable cause of death?
Anatomical waste should be disposed off in which color-coded bag?
A crush injury during a vehicular accident most commonly ruptures which organ?

A 30-year-old unmarried woman came to a doctor and requested her to induce an abortion. The doctor refused and told the women there is severe punishment for criminal abortion in Pakistan. What is the punishment of criminal abortion before babies' organs are formed in Pakistan?
In Pakistan, on which grounds is abortion justifiable?

A graduate student is planning to make a high-altitude climb in South America while on vacation. He will not have time to acclimate slowly to the altitude. What drug is useful in preventing high-altitude sickness?
What is the net filtration pressure if the value of capillary pressure is 60 mm H₂O, glomerular oncotic pressure is 32 mm H₂O, and Bowman's hydrostatic pressure is 18 mm H₂O?

A 60-year-old patient has a clinical history of frequent episodes of renal colic with calcium-containing stones. His clinical workup indicates that he has a defect in proximal tubular calcium reabsorption. Which of the following diuretic agent is most useful in the treatment of recurrent calcium stones?

A 60-year-old man seeks medical attention because of recurrent urinary tract infections. The patient has a history of increasing difficulty in urination, decreased flow, straining, and hesitancy over the last several months. Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) level is mildly elevated and a prostate biopsy proves benign. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management of this patient with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH)?

answers.option: Alpha adrenergic blocker and 5-alpha reductase inhibitor

question: A 55-year-old man presents with fever and pain in the perineal region. Upon further questioning, he also complains of frequency, urgency, dysuria, and a decreased urinary stream. On physical examination his abdomen Is soft, non-distended, and non-tender, Digital Rectal examination (DRE) demonstrates exquisite tenderness on the anterior aspect. Laboratory investigation reveals leukocytosis and findings on urinalysis are consistent with a bacterial infection. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 36-year-old man presents to the emergency room with renal colic. His vital signs are normal and a urinalysis shows microscopic hematuria. A radiograph reveals a 1.6 cm stone. Which of the following Is the most appropriate management of this patient?

answers.option: Open surgery to remove the stone

question: A 32-year-old man presents with an asymptomatic mass in his right testicle. On examination, the mass cannot be transilluminated. Ultrasound shows a solid mass in the right testicle. Which of the following is the most accurate method in obtaining a diagnosis of testicular cancer?

answers.option: Incisional biopsy of testicular mass through a scrotal incision
Serum level of alpha-fetoprotein and beta human chorionic gonadotropin
Excisional biopsy of the testicular mass with scrotal incision

question: A 10-year-old boy presents to the emergency room with pain in the left testicle. The pain is acute in onset and began 1 hour ago. On physical examination, he has a high riding, firm, and markedly tender left testis. The right testicle is normal. Urinalysis is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate management of this patient?

answers.option: Manual detorsion of the left testicle with internal rotation towards the thigh, orchidopexy if the condition recurs
Manual detorsion of the left testicle with external rotation towards the thigh, orchidopexy if the condition recurs

question: Which one of the following statistical tests Is appropriate for normally distributed continuous data?
Which of the following sample sizes is appropriate for applying the Z test?
Which type of statistics can be calculated by a one-way ANOVA test?

A student has to present the association of liver cancer with five different socioeconomic and demographic variables along with their respective P-values and 95% confidence intervals. Which of the following data presentations would be most suitable for this scenario?
You are asked to examine a female suspected of sexual assault. Examination findings reveal a deflorated female. Which of the following defines defloration?
You are asked to examine a female suspected of sexual assault. Examination findings reveal a ruptured hymen. What is the most common site of rupture of the hymen in a virgin female?
What is the type of sexual perversion in which the person gets sexual gratification by inflicting pain on their partner?
A student has to compare the mean cholesterol levels among the four different groups of smokers. Which of the following hypothesis tests would be suitable for the above scenario?
Which of the following statements about the anatomy of the kidneys is correct?

answers.option: Medullary rays contain collection of renal corpuscles
Vasa recta are not present in the renal pyramids
Caliber of afferent arterioles is greater than the efferent arterioles
Renal columns are the extensions of renal cortex between the adjacent renal pyramids
Cortical nephrons have lengthier loops of Henle than the juxtaglomerular nephrons

question: Which of the following statements is correct about the development of the urinary system?

answers.option: Metanephric blastema is present at upper thoracic region
Ureteric buds develop into proximal convoluted tubules
Loops of Henle develop from metanephric blastema
Mesonephric tissue is responsible for the formation of permanent kidneys
Collecting ducts develop from metanephric blastema

question: Every molecule of glucose gets reabsorbed in the proximal convoluted tubule. About 90% of the glucose that is filtered is reabsorbed in the initial segment of the proximal convoluted tubule. Which glucose transporter plays a key role in transporting the majority of glucose from the brush border epithelium into the cell, out of the tubular lumen?
In which segment of the renal tubule are the sodium-hydrogen antiporters responsible for hydrogen ion secretion situated?

During a clinical interview, the doctor asked the patient “What were your feelings when you were talking about a fractured arm, as you mentioned that you were a physical trainer and could easily lift ten-kilogram weight ten times in a minute”. Asking about emotions and feelings attached to various symptoms and problems in an interview is an example of which of the following?
Upon taking a detailed history from an offender, it is revealed that he frequently has intercourse with animals. What Is this sexual perversion termed?

A 3-year-old boy presents with fever, dysuria, oliguria, and intense pain in the abdomen. Physical examination shows a prominent suprapubic area which is dull on percussion. Urinalysis reveals red blood cells but no proteinuria. A diagnosis of hydronephrosis was made. What is the important morphological feature of hydronephrosis?

answers.option: Dilatation of renal calyces and pelvis with atrophy of renal parenchyma
Enlarged kidneys with multiple cysts in the cortex and medulla
Cortical tubulointerstitial damage with small contracted kidney
Cortical scarring and shrinking caused by thickening and hyalinization of the vessel walls
Patchy interstitial suppurative inflammation, intratubular aggregates of neutrophilic tubulitis, and tubular necrosis

question: An 8-month-old infant was diagnosed with autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease. Which one of the following other abnormalities can develop in this patient?
Which of the following statements are false regarding the etiology and pathogenesis of pyelonephritis and urinary tract infection?

answers.option: It can be caused by ascending infection from the bladder or through hematogenous dissemination
The most common causative agent is E. coli
It is more common in males
It is more common in females

question: A 45-year-old woman has angina pectoris, polyuria, and polydipsia for the past 5 years. On physical examination, she has a body mass index (BMI) of 32 kg/m². Laboratory studies show an HbA1C of 10%. Urinalysis shows macroalbuminuria, with no ketonuria. Which one of the following morphological changes can be attributed to the patient's proteinuria?
Which of the following is not a filtration barrier in kidneys?

answers.option: Negative charge in the glomerular basement membrane

question: Nephrotic syndrome is a clinical complex characterized by massive proteinuria of 3.5 gm or more of protein loss per 24 hours, hypoalbuminemia, generalized edema, hyperlipidemia, and lipiduria. Which of the following causes of nephrotic syndrome is steroid-responsive?

A clinical study is performed on laboratory findings in subjects with renal diseases. Loss of physiologic function accompanies many diseases. Loss of which of the following renal functions is most likely to be identified by laboratory measurement of the urine-specific gravity following water deprivation?

A 5-year-old boy presents with generalized and periorbital edema. Further investigations show hypoalbuminemia, lipiduria, and 3.74 g proteinuria. Which of the following conditions is the most likely cause in this patient?

A 30-year-old man complains of puffiness around his eyes and swelling of his feet for 2 weeks. On examination, his blood pressure is 155/95 mm Hg. Urine microscopic examination reveals oval fat bodies. Which of the following conditions is he most likely to have?

Tubulointerstitial nephritis is inflammation that affects the tubules and the tissue surrounding them called "Interstitial tissue." The onset of tubulointerstitial nephritis may be acute (sudden) or chronic (gradual) and often results in kidney failure. Which of the following is the most common cause of acute tubulointerstitial nephritis?

answers.option: Damage from a drug (not an allergic reaction)

question: A 32-year-old case of diabetes mellitus and using alcohol occasionally, presented with loose stools, watery in consistency for 3 days. He has around 10-12 of these episodes every day. On examination, he was dehydrated, with around 200 ml of urine output in 24 hours. Initial investigation showed an Hb of 14.8 mg/dL, TLC 11.2 x 10³/L, platelet count of 324x 10³/L, K⁺ 9.4 mEq/L, HCO₃⁻ 18, Urea: 94. Among the mentioned laboratory parameters which of the following is a highly indicative marker for hemodialysis?

A 24-year-old female presented with decreased urination and hematuria for 2 days. She has been unwell for the past 15 days with a severe sore throat and high-grade fever with chills. On examination, she has a blood pressure of 150/100 mmHg, pulse of 94/min, and temperature of 100°F. Systemic and general physical examinations were unremarkable. Which of the following urinary casts is most specific for her illness?

A 50-year-old male is admitted to the medical ward with a history of abdominal distention and pedal edema. He is diagnosed as a case of chronic liver disease (cirrhosis). A complete blood count (CBC) shows a Hb of 10 mg/dL, WBC 3x10 mm³, platelet count 105x10 mm³, serum albumin 2.7mg/dl, prothrombin time 18 sec, (normal: 11-14 sec). Serum sodium is 122 mEq/L, serum K⁺ 3.6 mg/L, creatinine 1.1 mg/dl. What is the cause of hyponatremia in this patient according to history and physical examination?

A 60-year-old male known diabetic for 8 years, taking oral hypoglycemic drugs is admitted to the medical intensive care unit (ICU) with an altered level of consciousness. There is no history of fever. There are no signs of meningeal irritation. Investigation: complete blood count (CBC) 11 mg/dL, WBC 5X10⁹ mm³, platelet count of 162 x10⁹ mm³. Random blood sugar (RBS) of 590 mg/dL, creatinine 1.2 mg/dL, serum sodium 168mg/dL, and a serum potassium of 3.9 mg/dl. For treating this patient, which of the following should not be given at this time to correct metabolic and electrolyte problems?

A 55-year-old male patient with poorly controlled diabetes mellitus presented with high-grade fever with chills, loin pain & tenderness over kidneys. His ultrasound shows hydroureter and hydronephrosis on the right side. What is the most appropriate management?

answers.option: Can be managed as outpatient on oral antibiotics
Should be given I/V antibiotics empirically
Should be admitted given I/V antibiotics and drainage by percutaneous nephrostomy
Should be given I/V fluids & cranberry juice

question: A 25-year-old pregnant female is advised a urine analysis and urine culture at 12 weeks of gestation. Which one of the following is correct regarding asymptomatic bacteriuria?

answers.option: More than 10⁵ organisms/ml is regarded as significant
Up to 10 organisms/ml is considered diagnostic
Normal urine culture does not exclude asymptomatic bacteriuria
Any number of organisms is regarded as significant
More than 10³ organisms/ml is regarded as significant

question: A 49-year-old male known diabetic, went for a follow-up renal check-up and reports an eGFR of 36ml/min/1.73 m². He was carrying his report from 4 months back, showing Urea: 78 mg/dL, serum creatinine 2.3 mg/dL, eGFR was 38 ml/min/1.73 m², and albumin: creatinine ratio was 300 mg/g. What will be the stage of his disease?

A 50-year-old male, a known case of diabetes mellitus and hypertension comes to the emergency department with complaints of decreased appetite, easy fatigability, and progressive shortness of breath for the last 4-5 months. On examination, blood pressure was 165/90 mm of Hg, pulse 85 beats/min, and respiratory rate 26/min. He appears pale, with periorbital puffiness and bilateral pedal edema present. Lab parameters show an Hb of 8.0 mg/dL, a normal TLC and platelet count, BUN was 60, and serum creatinine was 3.2 mg/dL. Potassium was also high. An 8-month-old report showed the same levels of deranged renal parameters. What will be the best possible diagnosis?

A 45-year-old male patient has recently been diagnosed with advanced-stage stomach cancer. The doctor discloses this news to the family and does not talk about it to the patient on their request. The patient comes to know about it later from other staff and goes into shock and depression subsequently. Which of the following disclosure models the doctor should most likely to be followed in this case?
Which of the following is an absolute contraindication to intravenous pyelography?
Ultrasound of kidneys is the key radiologic modality in patients with renal failure as it is useful in assessment of which of the following?

A 1-year-old female baby is admitted to PICU with acute gastroenteritis with severe dehydration. Her urine output is 0.8ml/kg/hr. Her serum sodium is 128meq/dl, K is 5.3 mEq/dl and serum creatinine is 2.5 mg/dL. CBC is normal. What is the most likely complication she has developed?

A 3-year-old boy presents to the clinic with a history of failure to thrive, poor appetite for 6 months, and nausea, and vomiting for 2 weeks. On examination, his height is 78 cm and his weight is 8 kg. His labs show serum creatinine 2.0 mg/dL. His GFR calculated is 45%. What is his most likely stage of chronic renal disease?
